Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: TYPE A - Isomotive dielectrophoresis for enhanced analyses of cell subpopulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
An award is made to the University of Louisville to develop an isomotive dielectrophoresis (isoDEP) microfluidic device that will extract dielectric properties of individual cells. IsoDEP can be used in applications where cell identification and analysis is critical such as studying phytoplankton populations for environmental monitoring, bacteria identification for monitoring food safety, or identifying cancerous cells. Details of the isoDEP device will be disseminated to the local biological community and the general public through technical presentations and social media. Educational outreach will include the exposure of isoDEP physics and instrument development to undergraduate students from rural impoverished regions of Appalachia and to high school students from Central High School, one of the oldest urban secondary schools in Kentucky.

The analysis of individual cells within a population can monitor environmental conditions or assess human health. In particular, dielectric properties provide insight into cell conditions and can be used to identify and characterize cell sub-populations. For example, cell properties such as membrane capacitance, membrane resistance, and cytoplasmic conductivity directly reflect the cell's biological structure. This project will extract dielectric measurements through particle tracking under an electrokinetic environment at a rate of at least one order of magnitude greater than current methods. Through collaboration with Murray State University, freshwater phytoplankton analysis will be conducted for environmental monitoring. In collaboration with a local small business (Ikotech, LLC), an additional objective of this research is to develop an isoDEP microfluidic instrument to be used by scientists worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project was to design and test a unique lab-on-a-chip device that was able to extract the individual dielectric properties of suspended particles and cells at a rate of at least one magnitude faster than current electrokinetic microfluidic devices. The measurement of a cell’s dielectric properties (ex: cytoplasm conductivity and membrane capacitance) is directly related to their general health and physiology. Further, such electrokinetic measurements are conducted in real-time and without the use of fluorescent labels. This simplified approach will benefit biological research communities who are interested in label-free identification and analysis of cells and their subpopulations.

The electrokinetic characterization technique used in this study was a variation of dielectrophoresis (DEP). DEP has traditionally been used for particle concentration and/or sorting; however, through this project we demonstrated that DEP could be used as an analytical tool via induced particle translation. Thus, straightforward cell analysis is enabled using established particle tracking techniques; this significant feature of our isoDEP platform enables automated characterization.

Our specific variation, called isomotive dielectrophoresis (isoDEP), was introduced decades ago using macroscale configurations (with accompanying large voltages!). Through this project our team was able to apply modern microfabrication techniques to miniaturize isoDEP, therefore making this technique portable and more widely available to biological researchers. Further, our approach was able to overcome current limitations associated with portable electrokinetic microfluidic devices that analyze individual cells, namely such devices are either high throughput with low sensitivity or low throughput with high sensitivity. Our platform was able to measure the response of individual particles at multiple frequencies (i.e. high sensitivity) at a rate one to two orders of magnitude greater than a competing technology (electrorotation). We also discovered a continuous-flow variation of isoDEP that would further enhance device throughput.

The microscale adaption of our platform, as we found out, was nontrivial. While testing several of our designs we discovered sources of unwanted electrohydrodynamics that would significantly alter the desired trajectory of our particles. We studied relevant fundamental physics in more detail and developed scaling laws for isoDEP device design to reduce unwanted electrokinetics. Further, our design approach can be readily applied to many other microscale electrokinetic devices where researchers want to eliminate similar unwanted electrohydrodynamics. We applied this scaling law design approach towards both microelectrode-based devices and insulator-based devices – the two most typical approaches to DEP.

This platform provides the foundation for the application of isoDEP towards a commercial application and ultimately getting this technique into the hands of biologists. As such, through this project our research team has established collaborations with cell biologists. Work is ongoing to apply dielectric characterization of cells with an emphasis on the physiological response to their environment (phytoplankton, marine cells, etc.). For example, our collaborative work has demonstrated how DEP can be used to characterize late embryogenesis abundant proteins which are found in desiccation-tolerant species. As such, our team demonstrated that DEP can be used as an alternative analytical technique, providing cell biologist with a complimentary tool to gain insight into cell physiology.
